questions.text: A patient is under radioiodine treatment for a few months for hyperthyroidism. Which of the following parameter is best to access his thyroid function during the course?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unbound T4 Iatrogenic hypothyroidism is a common cause of hypothyroidism and can often be detected by screening before symptoms develop eg following radioiodine treatment. Because TSH levels are suppressed by hyperthyroidism, unbound T4 levels are a better measure of thyroid function than TSH in the months following radioiodine treatment. Low-dose thyroxine treatment can be withdrawn if recovery occurs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: TSH levels are suppressed by hyperthyroidism so NOT a good parameter. Option: C: Circulating unbound T3 levels are not indicated. Option: D : Not accessed.

questions.text: Which of the following has been used successfully as public health measures to improve iodine intake and eliminate iodine deficiency?

options.label: B
options.text: A single bolus of oral iodized oil

options.label: C
options.text: A single bolus of intramuscular iodized oil

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the Above Iodine deficiency is responsible for endemic goitre and cretinism but is an uncommon cause of adult hypothyroidism unless the iodine intake is very low or there are complicating factors, such as the consumption of thiocyanates in cassava or selenium deficiency. Although hypothyroidism due to iodine deficiency can be treated with thyroxine, public health measures to improve iodine intake should be advocated to eliminate this problem. Iodized salt or bread or a single bolus of oral or intramuscular iodized oil have all been used successfully.

Highyeild:

Government actions in IDD Universal salt iodization as sole strategy to address IDD. Distribution of iodized salt in remote districts at subsidized rates. Implementation of lodized Salt Social marketing Campaign. • Monitoring of iodized salt at the entry points, regional and national levels.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, and C. All the options ar correct regarding the public health measures to improve iodine intake and eliminate iodine deficiency.

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida female is referred from Obstetric OPD for evaluation of treatment of hypothyroidism. All of the following are the right statements about it EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: Thyroid function should be evaluated immediately after pregnancy is confirmed

options.label: B
options.text: Thyroid function should be evaluated every 10 weeks during the first half of the pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: The levothyroxine dose may need to be increased by up to 45% during pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: Women should increase levothyroxine from once-daily dosing to nine doses per week as soon as pregnancy is confirmed

questions.correct_answer: B. Thyroid function should be evaluated every 10 weeks during the first half of the pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thyroid function should be evaluated every 10 weeks during the first half of the pregnancy Thyroid function should be evaluated immediately after pregnancy is confirmed and every 4 weeks during the first half of the pregnancy, with less frequent testing after 20 weeks gestation (every 6–8 weeks depending on whether levothyroxine dose adjustment is ongoing).

Highyeild:

THYROIDAND PREGNANCY Physiological changes: TBG 1:- Total T4 ↑ Free T4, TSH - (N) HCG 1, TSH! Normal values of TSH in pregnancy: 1st trimester - 0.1-2.5 I.U

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Prior to conception, levothyroxine therapy should be targeted to maintain a serum TSH in the normal range but <2.5 mIU/L for hypothyroid women. Thus thyroid function should be evaluated immediately after pregnancy is confirmed. Options: C, D: The levothyroxine dose may need to be increased by up to 45% during pregnancy. Women should increase levothyroxine from once-daily dosing to nine doses per week as soon as pregnancy is confirmed , to anticipate this change. After delivery, levothyroxine doses typically return to prepregnancy levels. Pregnant women should be counselled to separate the ingestion of prenatal vitamins and iron supplements from levothyroxine.

questions.text: A 27-year-old 6 weeks pregnant female presents with complaints of palpitations, weight loss and heat intolerance. Which of the following is used for the treatment of her illness in the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Propylthiouracil If available, propylthiouracil should be used until 14–16 weeks gestation because of the association of rare cases of methimazole/ carbimazole embryopathy, including aplasia cutis and other defects, such as choanal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistulae .

Option: D : Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications to radioiodine treatment, but patients can conceive safely 6 months after treatment.

Extraedge:

Due to the hepatotoxicity of propylthiouracil, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has limited indications for its use in the first trimester of pregnancy, the treatment of thyroid storm, and patients with minor adverse reactions to methimazole.

questions.text: A patient with thyrotoxicosis is evaluated with thyroid scintigraphy and the result is shown in the image. What is the finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Toxic adenoma In a toxic adenoma, there is a lack of uptake of isotope by the rest of the thyroid gland due to suppression of serum TSH.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department (ED) with palpitations. On questioning, she notes heat intolerance, nervousness, and insomnia. On physical examination, the physician notes a fine tremor, diffuse non-pitting edema of the anterior lower leg, and bulging of both of her eyes. What finding on the blood test would confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti-thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies Anti–thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies are pathognomonic for Graves’ disease, as is suggested by this patient’s symptoms of thyrotoxicosis with exophthalmos and pretibial myxedema These antibodies mediate the disease by provoking a continuous and inappropriate release of thyroid hormone, which results in the clinical picture described.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: While thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels are decreased in Graves’ disease, they are also decreased in all other forms of hyperthyroidism, so a decreased TSH level would be suggestive of, but not diagnostic for, Graves’ disease. Option C: An increased creatine kinase–myocardial bound fraction is sometimes seen in conjunction with hypothyroidism. In this case, this patient most likely has Graves’ disease, a form of hyperthyroidism. Option D: This patient most likely has Graves’ disease, and as a form of hyperthyroidism, her TSH level will be decreased, not increased.

questions.text: What of the following is the result of the deletion of the paternal copies of the imprinted SNRPN gene, the NECDIN gene, and possibly other genes on chromosome 15q?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prader-Willi syndrome Prader-Willi syndrome is a contiguous gene syndrome that results from the deletion of the paternal copies of the imprinted SNRPN gene, the NECDIN gene, and possibly other genes on chromosome 15q. Prader-Willi syndrome is associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, hyperphagia-obesity, chronic muscle hypotonia, mental retardation, and adult-onset diabetes mellitus . Multiple somatic defects also involve the skull, eyes, ears, hands, and feet

questions.text: The patient, a female, 24 years old has a normal blood level of triiodothyronine. But there is an increasing level of TSH. There are no apparent clinical signs in this patient. She is planning to have a baby. What will you advise this patient?

Solution:

Start with a low dose of levothyroxine This is the case of subclinical hypothyroidism Here the patient is having normal levels of blood triiodothyronine But there is an increased level of TSH and absence of any apparent clinical signs There is no universally accepted recommendation for the management of subclinical hypothyroidism But here it is given that the patient is trying to get pregnant It is important to confirm any elevation of TSH is sustained over a three-month period before treatment is given Treatment is administered by starting with a low dose of levothyroxine (25-50microgram/d) with the goal of normalising TSH
